bestBHT.bht: At the end of Jesus' last journey to Jerusalem, the people were very attentive, hanging upon His words. They displayed an anxious desire, a fixed attention, a cleaving to Him, and an unwillingness to 'leave' Him, so that they might hear His words. The Sanhedrin were unsure of how to seize Him and feared the people's potential rescue. Jesus's deep feelings over sinners serve as a warning, showing that they are in danger. It is right for us to have similar lively affections in our religious experiences.

Henry Alford: It is rightly however placed at the end of a chapter, for it forms a close to the long section wherein the last journey to Jerusalem has been described.
Albert Barnes: Very attentive - literally, 'hung upon him' to hear him. The word denotes an anxious desire, a fixed attention, a cleaving to him, and an unwillingness to 'leave' him, so that they might hear his words.
When the Lord Jesus weeps over sinners, it is the fullest proof that they are in danger.
Deep feeling, gushing emotions, lively affections, are proper in religion. If the Saviour wept, it is not improper for us to weep - it is right.
Marvin Vincent: Were very attentive [εξεκρεματο] . Only here in New Testament.
Lit., as Rev., hung upon him. Tynd., stuck by him. ===Luke 20:0
Archibald T. Robertson: The whole nation hanging upon the words of Jesus as if in suspense in mid-air.
John Gill: They could not find an opportunity of seizing him, nor any advantage against him; they knew not what steps to take, nor how to bring about their wicked design of destroying him.
They heard him with great eagerness and diligence, and were ready to catch every word that dropped from his lips.

The sanhedrim were at a loss what method to make use of to gain their point; and they feared the people, should they seize him publicly, lest they should rise and rescue him, and cause a tumult and disturbance.

bhtAttempts.bht: At the end of a long section describing Jesus' last journey to Jerusalem, the people in Luke 19:48 were very attentive to hear him. They hung upon His words, displaying an anxious desire, fixed attention, and cleaving to Him. The whole nation seemed to be in suspense, hanging upon the words of Jesus as if in mid-air. The Sanhedrin were at a loss of what steps to take to seize Him and bring about their wicked design of destroying Him, fearing the people would rise and cause a tumult if they seized Him publicly. Jesus's deep feelings and gushing emotions over sinners serve as a warning that they are in danger, and it is right for us to have similar lively affections in our own religious experiences.

At the end of Jesus' last journey to Jerusalem, people were very attentive, hanging upon His words. They displayed an anxious desire, fixed attention, and cleaving to Him, as if in suspense in mid-air. The Sanhedrin were unsure of how to seize Him and feared the people's potential rescue and subsequent tumult. Jesus's deep feelings and gushing emotions over sinners serve as a warning. It is right for us to have similar lively affections in our religious experiences.

At the end of Jesus' last journey to Jerusalem, people were very attentive, hanging upon His words. They hung upon Him, displaying an anxious desire and fixed attention. The Sanhedrin were unsure of how to seize Him and feared the people's potential rescue. Jesus's deep feelings over sinners serve as a warning. It is right for us to have similar lively affections in our religious experiences.

At the end of Jesus' last journey to Jerusalem, the people were very attentive, hanging upon His words. They hung upon Him, displaying an anxious desire and fixed attention, unwilling to leave Him. The Sanhedrin were unsure of how to seize Him and feared the people's potential rescue. Jesus's deep feelings over sinners serve as a warning. It is right for us to have similar lively affections in our religious experiences.

At the end of Jesus' last journey to Jerusalem, the people were very attentive, hanging upon His words. They displayed an anxious desire, a fixed attention, a cleaving to Him, and an unwillingness to 'leave' Him, so that they might hear His words. The Sanhedrin were unsure of how to seize Him and feared the people's potential rescue. Jesus's deep feelings over sinners serve as a warning, showing that they are in danger. It is right for us to have similar lively affections in our religious experiences.
